original_case_data.name: Glover v. City of Laguna Beach
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Homeless disabled individuals in Laguna Beach California
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
This lawsuit was brought by several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private counsel, accused the city and the Laguna Beach Police Department (LBPD) of violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution by targeting disabled homeless people under laws restricting camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs argued that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter created by the county as part of the settlement of a previous lawsuit, did not provide adequate accommodations for homeless persons with disabilities, leaving them with no viable alternative to camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs brought their suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgement Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. They sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees. More specifically, the plaintiffs sought a declaration that the city was violating the law and an injunction preventing the city from enforcing anti-camping laws and requiring that the city provide new accommodations suitable for housing homeless people with disabilities.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction that would prevent the LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending the final outcome of the suit. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the plaintiffs' motion on February 10, 2016, finding that the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive relief were unlikely to succeed at trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint in order to introduce additional plaintiffs. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification.

On October 31, 2016, both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The plaintiffs moved for summary judgment to establish that the defendants violated (1) the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and analogous provisions of the California Constitution, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs’ claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment claims and the substantive due process claims. Judge Guilford denied both parties' motions for summary judgment on the ADA and RA claims.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, only with respect to the plaintiffs' remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class consisting of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of settlement negotiations, during which the parties exchanged voluminous discovery and engaged multiple experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement agreement with the court on June 6, 2018. Under the terms of the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council will adopt a resolution affirming its commitment to end homelessness in the City of Laguna Beach. Additionally, the City agreed to a number of measures designed to accommodate disabled persons experiencing homelessness in Laguna Beach. Such measures include, for instance, the continued designation of a full-time City employee to serve as the City’s “ADA Coordinator;” the adaptation of existing grievance procedures to more directly address the needs of ASL guests; the permanent posting of a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the process for requesting and obtaining reasonable accommodations; and more. The plaintiffs' counsel did not seek attorneys' fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved the motion on November 5, 2020. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.
original_case_data.summary_short: Several disabled homeless persons sue the City of Luguna Beach, California, in the U.S. District Court of Central California, alleging that the Laguna Beach Police Department enforces anti-camping laws against them despite the city's failure to provide alternative housing that can accommodate their disabilities, in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution. Judge Andrew J. Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class-certification. After Judge Guilford ruled on cross-motions for summary judgment, the only remaining issues were the plaintiffs' ADA and RA claims. After extensive settlement negotiations, the parties agreed to a settlement, which the court continues to enforce.
original_case_data.summary_tiny: Disabled homeless people sue Laguna Beach California for anti-camping laws and lack of accommodations. @ACLU_SoCal

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction that would prevent the LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending the final outcome of the suit. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the plaintiffs' motion on February 10, 2016, finding that the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive relief were unlikely to succeed at trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint in order to introduce additional plaintiffs. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification.

On October 31, 2016, both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The plaintiffs moved for summary judgment to establish that the defendants violated (1) the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and analogous provisions of the California Constitution, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs’ claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment claims and the substantive due process claims. Judge Guilford denied both parties' motions for summary judgment on the ADA and RA claims.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, only with respect to the plaintiffs' remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class consisting of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of settlement negotiations, during which the parties exchanged voluminous discovery and engaged multiple experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement agreement with the court on June 6, 2018. Under the terms of the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council will adopt a resolution affirming its commitment to end homelessness in the City of Laguna Beach. Additionally, the City agreed to a number of measures designed to accommodate disabled persons experiencing homelessness in Laguna Beach. Such measures include, for instance, the continued designation of a full-time City employee to serve as the City’s “ADA Coordinator;” the adaptation of existing grievance procedures to more directly address the needs of ASL guests; the permanent posting of a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the process for requesting and obtaining reasonable accommodations; and more. 2.transformed_text:
This lawsuit was initiated in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California by several homeless individuals with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach and its Police Department (LBPD). Represented by the Southern California ACLU and private counsel, plaintiffs alleged violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution. The core accusation was that defendants targeted disabled homeless persons through anti-camping ordinances, despite the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL) providing inadequate accommodations for those with disabilities, thereby leaving no viable alternative to public camping. The action was brought under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgment Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. Plaintiffs sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees, specifically requesting a declaration of illegality and an injunction against anti-camping enforcement, coupled with a mandate for new, suitable accommodations.

Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction to halt LBPD enforcement of anti-camping laws against disabled homeless individuals was denied by Judge Andrew J. Guilford on February 10, 2016, who found the claims for injunctive relief unlikely to succeed on the merits.

Following the filing of a second amended complaint to add plaintiffs, a motion for class certification was filed. On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted class certification in part, limiting the class to the plaintiffs' remaining ADA and RA claims. The certified class encompassed "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

The parties subsequently filed cross-motions for summary judgment. Plaintiffs sought summary judgment on their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment claims (and analogous California constitutional provisions) and their ADA and RA claims. Defendants moved for summary judgment on all claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted defendants' motion for summary judgment regarding the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment claims and the substantive due process claims. However, the court denied both parties' motions for summary judgment concerning the ADA and RA claims.

After nearly a year of settlement negotiations, which involved voluminous discovery and expert engagement, the parties agreed to settle all claims. A motion for preliminary approval of the proposed Class Claims Settlement Agreement was filed and subsequently granted. Under the settlement terms, the Laguna Beach City Council committed to adopting a resolution affirming its dedication to ending homelessness. The City also agreed to specific measures to accommodate disabled homeless persons, including designating a full-time ADA Coordinator, adapting ASL grievance procedures, and permanently posting a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL outlining the accommodation request process. Plaintiffs' counsel waived attorneys' fees.

The parties then sought final approval of the settlement agreement, which Judge Guilford granted on November 5, 2020. The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.

1.transformed_text:
This lawsuit was filed by several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach in federal court. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private lawyers, claimed the city and the Laguna Beach Police Department (LBPD) violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act (RA), and certain parts of the California Constitution. They argued the city did this by enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people. The plaintiffs stated that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter created by the county from a previous lawsuit, did not properly accommodate homeless persons with disabilities, leaving them no other choice but to camp in public spaces. The plaintiffs filed their lawsuit under federal and California law, including specific statutes like 42 U.S.C. §1983 and the Declaratory Judgment Act. They asked the court for several things: temporary and permanent orders to stop certain actions (injunctions), a declaration that the city was breaking the law, small financial compensation (nominal damages), and payment of their legal fees. Specifically, they wanted the court to declare the city's actions illegal and issue an order preventing the city from enforcing anti-camping laws. They also sought an order requiring the city to provide new, suitable housing options for disabled homeless individuals.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs asked for a temporary court order (a preliminary injunction) to stop the police from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people while the lawsuit was ongoing. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied this request on February 10, 2016. He found it unlikely that the plaintiffs would win their case for this type of order at a full trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs updated their complaint to add more plaintiffs to the case. Soon after, they asked the court to certify the case as a class action.

On October 31, 2016, both sides asked the judge for summary judgment. The plaintiffs sought summary judgment to prove that the defendants had violated: (1) protections against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and similar parts of the California Constitution, and (2) the ADA and RA. The defendants, on the other hand, asked for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims, seeking to have them dismissed. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford ruled in favor of the defendants for some claims, specifically those related to cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment and certain 'due process' claims. However, he denied both sides' requests for summary judgment on the ADA and RA claims, meaning those claims would proceed.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford partly approved the plaintiffs' request for class certification. He allowed it only for the remaining ADA and RA claims. The class included all homeless people in Laguna Beach with mental or physical disabilities, as defined by the Rehabilitation Act and ADA, who had been or were likely to be cited for violating specific anti-camping laws in the city.

After nearly a year of settlement talks, where both sides shared a lot of information and hired various experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit. They asked the court for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement on June 6, 2018. Under the settlement agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council agreed to formally commit to ending homelessness in the city. The City also agreed to several steps to help disabled homeless individuals in Laguna Beach. These steps included: appointing a full-time City employee as an "ADA Coordinator," changing existing complaint procedures to better serve ASL guests, and permanently posting a notice at the ASL explaining how to request reasonable accommodations, among other things. The plaintiffs' lawyers did not ask for attorney fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion asking for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved it on November 5, 2020. The court will continue to oversee the settlement to ensure it is followed.

Several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities sued the City of Laguna Beach in federal court. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private lawyers, claimed the city and its police department violated constitutional protections against cruel and unusual punishment and fair treatment, along with federal laws protecting people with disabilities, by enforcing anti-camping rules against disabled homeless individuals.

The plaintiffs argued that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter set up by the county after an earlier lawsuit, didn't properly help homeless people with disabilities. This, they said, left them no choice but to camp in public areas. The lawsuit was filed under federal and California law, including a law that allows people to sue government officials for violating their rights and the Declaratory Judgment Act, which lets courts officially state what the law is. They asked the court for several things: temporary and permanent court orders to stop certain actions (called injunctions), an official court statement that the city was breaking the law, a small amount of money as compensation, and payment of their legal fees. Specifically, they wanted the court to declare the city's actions illegal and issue an order preventing the city from enforcing anti-camping laws. They also sought an order requiring the city to provide new, suitable housing options for disabled homeless individuals.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs asked for a temporary court order, known as a preliminary injunction, to stop police from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people while the lawsuit was ongoing. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied this request on February 10, 2016. He believed it was unlikely the plaintiffs would win their case for this type of order at a full trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs updated their complaint to add more people to the case. Soon after, they asked the court to allow the lawsuit to represent a larger group of people in similar situations, known as a class action.

On October 31, 2016, both sides asked the judge for a quick decision without a full trial, known as summary judgment. The plaintiffs sought summary judgment to prove the defendants had violated constitutional protections against cruel and unusual punishment and fair treatment, as well as the federal disability laws. The defendants, on the other hand, asked for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims, seeking to have them dismissed. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford ruled in favor of the defendants for some claims, specifically those related to cruel and unusual punishment and claims about fair legal procedures. However, he denied both sides' requests for summary judgment on the federal disability law claims, meaning those claims would proceed to trial.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford partly approved the plaintiffs' request for class action status. He allowed it only for the remaining federal disability law claims. The class included all homeless people in Laguna Beach with mental or physical disabilities, as defined by federal disability laws, who had been or were likely to be cited for violating specific anti-camping laws in the city.

After nearly a year of settlement talks, during which both sides shared a lot of information and hired various experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit. They asked the court for initial approval of their proposed settlement on June 6, 2018. Under the settlement agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council agreed to formally commit to ending homelessness in the city. The City also agreed to several steps to help disabled homeless individuals in Laguna Beach. These steps included: appointing a full-time City employee as an "ADA Coordinator," changing existing complaint procedures to better serve ASL guests, and permanently posting a notice at the ASL explaining how to request reasonable accommodations, among other things. The plaintiffs' lawyers did not ask for attorney fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion asking for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved it on November 5, 2020. The court will continue to oversee the settlement to ensure it is followed.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine a group of students feeling like their school rules are unfair. Well, something similar happened in Laguna Beach. Several homeless people, who also had mental or physical disabilities, took the City of Laguna Beach to federal court. They, with help from the ACLU (a group that protects civil rights) and other lawyers, said the city and its police were breaking basic rules about how people should be treated. They claimed the city was violating their rights under the U.S. Constitution and federal laws meant to protect people with disabilities, especially by making them follow anti-camping rules even though they had nowhere else to go.

The homeless people argued that a small emergency shelter, called the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), which was set up by the county after a previous lawsuit, wasn't good enough for people with disabilities. They said this left them with no choice but to sleep outside in public places. Their lawsuit used federal and California laws, including one that lets people sue the government if their rights are violated, and another that allows a court to officially say what the law means in a situation. They asked the court for a few things: to issue orders (like a referee blowing a whistle) to stop the city from doing certain things, to officially state that the city was breaking the law, to get a small amount of money for damages, and to have their legal bills paid. More specifically, they wanted the court to say the city's actions were illegal and to stop the city from enforcing its anti-camping laws. They also wanted the court to make the city provide better housing options for disabled homeless people.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs asked for a temporary court order, kind of like a "pause button," to stop the police from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people while the lawsuit was still happening. But on February 10, 2016, Judge Andrew J. Guilford said no to this request. He felt it was unlikely the plaintiffs would win their entire case later on, so he didn't grant the temporary stop order.

A few months later, on May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs updated their lawsuit papers to include even more people. Soon after, they asked the court to make it a "class action" lawsuit. This means one lawsuit would represent a whole group of people who are in similar situations, making the legal process more efficient.

On October 31, 2016, both sides in the lawsuit asked the judge for a "summary judgment." This is like asking for a quick decision without needing a full trial, if they believe the facts are clear enough. The plaintiffs wanted the judge to rule that the city had definitely broken the rules about cruel and unusual punishment and fair treatment, and also the disability laws. The city, on the other hand, wanted the judge to dismiss all of the plaintiffs' claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford sided with the city on some parts, like the claims about cruel punishment and fair legal procedures. But he said no to both sides' requests for a quick decision on the federal disability law claims. This meant those specific claims would still need to go to a full trial.

Around the same time, on June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford agreed to part of the plaintiffs' request for a class action. He said it could only be a class action for the disability law claims that were still ongoing. The "class" (the group of people represented) included all homeless people in Laguna Beach with mental or physical disabilities (as defined by federal laws) who had already been, or were likely to be, given tickets for breaking specific anti-camping laws in the city.

After almost a year of talking things over, where both sides shared a lot of information and even brought in different experts, everyone agreed to settle the entire lawsuit. They asked the court to give its first approval to their proposed agreement on June 6, 2018. In this agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council promised to work towards ending homelessness in the city. The city also agreed to take several actions to help disabled homeless people in Laguna Beach. These actions included: hiring a full-time city employee to be an "ADA Coordinator" (someone who helps make sure the city follows disability laws), changing how people can make complaints so it's easier for ASL guests, and putting up a permanent sign at the ASL explaining how to ask for special help or changes if needed. Interestingly, the lawyers for the homeless people did not ask for their legal fees to be paid.

They went to a special federal court. They had help from the ACLU, which is a group that protects people's rights, and other lawyers. They said the city and its police were breaking important rules. These rules were about how people should be treated. They claimed the city was not following the U.S. Constitution and other laws that protect people with disabilities. The city had rules against sleeping outside. The homeless people said this was unfair because they had nowhere else to go.

They said this meant they had to sleep outside. So, they sued the city. Their lawsuit used laws from the U.S. government and California. One law lets people sue the government if their rights are broken. Another law lets a court officially say what the law means. They asked the court for several things. And they wanted the court to make the city offer better places for disabled homeless people to live.

This kind of lawsuit lets one case speak for a whole group of people. These people must be in similar situations. It makes the legal process work better.

But the city wanted the judge to throw out all the homeless people's claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford agreed with the city on some parts. These included the claims about cruel treatment and fair legal steps. But he said no to both sides' requests for a quick decision on the federal disability law claims. This meant those claims would still need a full trial.

0.text:
This lawsuit was brought by several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private counsel, accused the city and the Laguna Beach Police Department (LBPD) of violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution by targeting disabled homeless people under laws restricting camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs argued that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter created by the county as part of the settlement of a previous lawsuit, did not provide adequate accommodations for homeless persons with disabilities, leaving them with no viable alternative to camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs brought their suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgement Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. They sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees. More specifically, the plaintiffs sought a declaration that the city was violating the law and an injunction preventing the city from enforcing anti-camping laws and requiring that the city provide new accommodations suitable for housing homeless people with disabilities.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction that would prevent the LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending the final outcome of the suit. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the plaintiffs' motion on February 10, 2016, finding that the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive relief were unlikely to succeed at trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint in order to introduce additional plaintiffs. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification.

On October 31, 2016, both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The plaintiffs moved for summary judgment to establish that the defendants violated (1) the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and analogous provisions of the California Constitution, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs’ claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment claims and the substantive due process claims. Judge Guilford denied both parties' motions for summary judgment on the ADA and RA claims.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, only with respect to the plaintiffs' remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class consisting of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of settlement negotiations, during which the parties exchanged voluminous discovery and engaged multiple experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement agreement with the court on June 6, 2018. Under the terms of the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council will adopt a resolution affirming its commitment to end homelessness in the City of Laguna Beach. Additionally, the City agreed to a number of measures designed to accommodate disabled persons experiencing homelessness in Laguna Beach. Such measures include, for instance, the continued designation of a full-time City employee to serve as the City’s “ADA Coordinator;” the adaptation of existing grievance procedures to more directly address the needs of ASL guests; the permanent posting of a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the process for requesting and obtaining reasonable accommodations; and more. The plaintiffs' counsel did not seek attorneys' fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved the motion on November 5, 2020. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.

1.transformed_text:
This historical challenge began when several homeless individuals with mental and physical disabilities initiated a lawsuit against the City of Laguna Beach. Their motivation was clear: they felt the city and its police department were unfairly targeting them through anti-camping laws, violating their constitutional rights and protections under disability acts. They contended that the existing Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL) was inadequate for their needs, leaving them with no viable alternative to public spaces. Their ultimate goal was to secure a court order preventing the city from enforcing these laws without providing suitable accommodations, and to compel the city to establish new, accessible housing options.

Early in the proceedings, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, a strategic move to secure immediate relief and prevent further enforcement of the anti-camping laws while the broader case unfolded. However, the court denied this request, signaling that it did not yet see sufficient grounds for such an immediate, drastic intervention.

To strengthen their collective voice and broaden the impact of their claims, the plaintiffs later amended their complaint to include more individuals facing similar challenges. This was followed by a strategic move to certify the case as a class action, a crucial step to ensure that any eventual ruling would protect not just the named plaintiffs, but all similarly situated homeless individuals with disabilities in Laguna Beach.

As the case progressed, both sides sought summary judgment. This procedural step was a strategic attempt by each party to convince the court that the facts were so overwhelmingly in their favor on certain claims that a full trial was unnecessary. The plaintiffs aimed for an early victory on their constitutional and disability rights claims, while the defendants sought to dismiss the entire case. The court’s decision reflected a nuanced view: it dismissed the constitutional claims related to cruel and unusual punishment, suggesting those arguments lacked sufficient factual basis for trial, but allowed the disability rights claims under the ADA and Rehabilitation Act to proceed, indicating these still presented genuine disputes of fact.

Crucially, the court did grant the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, though limited to the remaining disability rights claims. This decision solidified the case's scope, transforming it from a dispute involving a few individuals into a collective action on behalf of a defined group of disabled homeless persons in Laguna Beach.

After nearly a year of intensive negotiations, the parties opted for a settlement rather than continuing towards a full trial. This decision reflected a mutual desire to achieve a practical resolution, avoiding the uncertainties and costs of prolonged litigation. The resulting Class Claims Settlement Agreement marked a significant turning point, with the City of Laguna Beach committing to a resolution affirming its dedication to ending homelessness and agreeing to implement specific measures designed to better accommodate disabled individuals experiencing homelessness, including dedicated staff and improved grievance procedures at the ASL.

The final act of this legal drama was the court's approval of the settlement agreement, a necessary step to formalize the agreed-upon terms and ensure their enforceability. This judicial endorsement brought the long-running dispute to a formal close, with the court retaining jurisdiction to ensure the City's adherence to its commitments.

original_case_data.name: Sostre v. Preiser
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Martin Sostre, a prison activist incarcerated in New York state prisons.
original_case_data.summary:
This is a historic case about prisoner rights in New York prisons. It's part of the Clearinghouse's collection of several cases brought by prisoners rights activist (and prisoner) Martin Sostre, whose wikipedia biography is here. 

On September 18, 1973, Sostre filed this lawsuit, pro se, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under §1983 a few days after he was allegedly beaten in the Segregation Unit at Clinton Prison, by a squad of seven or more officers, when he refused to bend over and spread his buttocks to exhibit his anus to them in the course of a strip search. The Complaint asserted seventeen separate causes of action, including wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, wrongful denial of visits from attorneys, clergy and friends, interference with mail, and wrongful punitive transfer from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port entered an order finding the complaint sufficient in law to permit the plaintiff to proceed in forma pauperis. The case then lay dormant in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre was able to obtain counsel; starting February, 1975, he was represented by radical prisoners’ rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham. 

Once Sostre obtained counsel, the Court agreed to hear his motion for preliminary relief, and entered an order directing that the plaintiff be brought into federal custody so he would not again have to face the forcible search and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing was held pertaining to Sostre’s request for preliminary relief. That request included that the defendants be enjoined from (1) enforcing a rule or regulation prohibiting inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard; (2) continuing to punish plaintiff for violating the no-beard rule or regulation; and (3) requiring the plaintiff to submit to a rectal search upon entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding that plaintiff failed to show likely success on the merits and irreparable injury. Judge Port ordered Sostre returned to the custody of the Clinton Prison. However, this order was stayed, with the agreement of defendants, pending disposition of plaintiff's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter to the district court. In an opinion written by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit concluded that it could not rule on the relief sought because the record did not establish what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they were such, required. Without knowing what the rules said, the court determined it could not ascertain whether the rules had been properly applied. It remanded the case to the district court for record development and re-evaluation. The opinion, however, reaffirmed that prison inmates are entitled to certain fundamental rights, and stated that limitations on such rights "must be supported by the legitimate and reasonable needs and exigencies of the institutional environment," and that these limitations must be narrowly tailored. The opinion also stated that the district court would not be amiss were it to continue the stay order in effect to keep plaintiff in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and been labeled as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, and he was released from custody. Presumably, this case was mooted as a result; federal records show that the case officially ended on Jan. 18, 1978.
original_case_data.summary_short: Sostre, an incarcerated individual, sued  the Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under §1983. Plaintiff alleged seventeen separate causes of action including wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, and more. Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages. Preliminary relief was denied by the district court, and on appeal, the appellate court reversed this decision and remanded the matter for development of a more detailed record. A few months later, Sostre was granted clemency by the New York Governor.
original_case_data.summary_tiny: New to the Sostre Collection at the Clearinghouse: a case by Sostre challenging the no-beard and rectal search rules at a prison in NY.

1.transformed_text:
This historic case concerns prisoner rights in New York prisons, forming part of the Clearinghouse's collection of litigation brought by prisoner rights activist Martin Sostre.

On September 18, 1973, Martin Sostre, proceeding pro se, initiated this §1983 action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons. The lawsuit followed an alleged beating of Sostre in the Segregation Unit at Clinton Prison, occurring after he refused a strip search requiring him to expose his anus. The Complaint asserted seventeen causes of action, including claims for wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, wrongful denial of visits from attorneys, clergy, and friends, interference with mail, and wrongful punitive transfer from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages. Judge Edmund Port issued an order on September 14, 1973, allowing Sostre to proceed in forma pauperis. The case remained dormant for sixteen months until Sostre secured representation from radical prisoners’ rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham in February 1975.

With counsel, Sostre moved for preliminary relief. The Court ordered Sostre brought into federal custody to prevent further forcible searches and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. A hearing on his request for preliminary relief sought to enjoin defendants from enforcing a rule prohibiting inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard, continuing to punish him for its violation, and requiring him to submit to a rectal search upon entering or leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding Sostre failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable injury, and ordered his return to Clinton Prison custody. This order was stayed by agreement of the defendants, pending Sostre's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. On June 19, 1975, the Second Circuit reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter. Judge Oakes, writing for the court, found the record insufficient to determine the precise requirements of the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, precluding a ruling on their proper application. The court remanded for further record development and re-evaluation, while reaffirming that prison inmates possess fundamental rights, and any limitations thereon must be narrowly tailored and supported by the legitimate and reasonable needs and exigencies of the institutional environment. The opinion also suggested the district court could maintain the stay order keeping Sostre in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763.

Sostre garnered international media attention and was recognized as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York Governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, leading to his release from custody. This action presumably mooted the case, which officially concluded on January 18, 1978.

The case then lay dormant in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre was able to obtain counsel; starting February, 1975, he was represented by radical prisoners’ rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham. 

Once Sostre obtained counsel, the Court agreed to hear his motion for preliminary relief, and entered an order directing that the plaintiff be brought into federal custody so he would not again have to face the forcible search and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing was held pertaining to Sostre’s request for preliminary relief. That request included that the defendants be enjoined from (1) enforcing a rule or regulation prohibiting inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard; (2) continuing to punish plaintiff for violating the no-beard rule or regulation; and (3) requiring the plaintiff to submit to a rectal search upon entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding that plaintiff failed to show likely success on the merits and irreparable injury. Judge Port ordered Sostre returned to the custody of the Clinton Prison. However, this order was stayed, with the agreement of defendants, pending disposition of plaintiff's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter to the district court. In an opinion written by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit concluded that it could not rule on the relief sought because the record did not establish what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they were such, required. Without knowing what the rules said, the court determined it could not ascertain whether the rules had been properly applied. It remanded the case to the district court for record development and re-evaluation. The opinion, however, reaffirmed that prison inmates are entitled to certain fundamental rights, and stated that limitations on such rights "must be supported by the legitimate and reasonable needs and exigencies of the institutional environment," and that these limitations must be narrowly tailored. The opinion also stated that the district court would not be amiss were it to continue the stay order in effect to keep plaintiff in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and been labeled as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, and he was released from custody. Presumably, this case was mooted as a result; federal records show that the case officially ended on Jan. 18, 1978.

1.transformed_text:
This is a historic case about prisoner rights in New York prisons. It is part of a collection of several cases brought by prisoners' rights advocate Martin Sostre, who was also a prisoner.

On September 18, 1973, Sostre filed this lawsuit on his own behalf in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under a federal civil rights law (Section 1983). This happened a few days after he was reportedly beaten in the isolated Segregation Unit at Clinton Prison by a group of seven or more officers. This occurred when he refused a strip search that required him to expose his anus. His complaint listed seventeen separate claims, including unfair punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, unfair enforcement of a no-beard rule, unfair demand for a rectal search, unfair denial of visits from attorneys, clergy, and friends, interference with his mail, and an unfair transfer as punishment from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre asked the court to declare his rights, order the prison to stop certain actions (injunctive relief), and pay him for damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port issued an order allowing Sostre to file the lawsuit without paying court fees because he was poor. The case then did not move forward in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre was able to get lawyers. Starting in February 1975, he was represented by lawyers who focused on prisoners’ rights, Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham.

Once Sostre got lawyers, the Court agreed to consider his request for immediate, temporary action. It ordered that Sostre be moved to federal custody so he would not again have to face forced searches and being sent back to the Segregation Unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing took place about Sostre’s request for temporary orders. That request asked that the prison officials be stopped from (1) enforcing a rule that prevented inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing beards; (2) continuing to punish Sostre for breaking the no-beard rule; and (3) making Sostre undergo a rectal search when entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit (a type of isolation unit) at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court rejected the request for temporary orders. The court found that Sostre had not shown he was likely to win the case or that he would suffer serious, lasting harm. Judge Port ordered Sostre sent back to Clinton Prison. However, this order was put on hold, with the agreement of the prison officials, while Sostre appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court overturned the lower court's decision to deny temporary orders and sent the case back to the district court. In an opinion written by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit found it could not decide on the requested orders because the case file didn't clearly show what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they existed, actually required. Without knowing what the rules said, the court determined it could not figure out if the rules had been used correctly. It sent the case back to the district court so more information could be gathered and the matter could be looked at again. The opinion, however, confirmed that prisoners have certain basic rights. It stated that any limits on these rights "must be based on the valid and practical needs of the prison environment," and these limits must be carefully designed to be as minimal as possible. The opinion also stated that the district court would be correct to keep the hold order in place, allowing Sostre to remain in federal custody.

By this time, Sostre had received international media attention and was called a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey gave Sostre clemency (a type of pardon), and he was released from custody. This likely made the case irrelevant or "moot" as a result; federal records show that the case officially closed on January 18, 1978.

The court ordered Sostre to be moved into federal custody, which means he would be held by federal officials. This was so he wouldn't have to go through more forced searches or be put back in the isolation unit. In March 1975, the court held a hearing, like a mini-trial, to discuss Sostre's request for these temporary orders. 1.transformed_text:
This historic case chronicles the legal saga of Martin Sostre, a prominent prisoner rights activist, whose efforts significantly shaped the discourse on inmate liberties in New York.

Sostre initiated this lawsuit in September 1973, acting on his own behalf, to challenge a series of alleged abuses he endured in prison. His decision to sue New York State's Commissioner of Corrections and various wardens stemmed from a severe beating he reportedly suffered after refusing a humiliating strip search. His comprehensive complaint outlined seventeen grievances, including wrongful confinement, the arbitrary enforcement of a no-beard rule, the invasive rectal search, and interference with his communications and visits. Through this legal action, Sostre sought not only to halt these practices and secure monetary compensation but, more broadly, to establish and protect fundamental rights for himself and other incarcerated individuals.

Initially, the court recognized the legitimacy of his claims, allowing him to proceed despite his indigent status. The case then entered a period of dormancy, awaiting the critical moment when Sostre could secure legal representation. In February 1975, his cause gained formidable support from radical prisoners' rights lawyers, Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham, marking a turning point in the litigation.

With counsel, Sostre's legal team strategically moved for preliminary relief, aiming to secure immediate protection from the very conditions he was challenging. This motion sought to prevent further enforcement of the no-beard rule and the invasive rectal searches, and crucially, to transfer Sostre into federal custody, thereby shielding him from continued harm while the broader case unfolded. The court acknowledged the urgency, ordering his transfer to federal custody.

However, the district court ultimately denied Sostre's request for this immediate protection. This decision reflected the prison authorities' initial success in asserting their discretion over inmate management, as the court found Sostre had not sufficiently demonstrated likely success on the merits or irreparable harm. Despite this setback, the court agreed to stay its order returning Sostre to state custody, signaling an acknowledgment of the ongoing legal dispute and the potential for a higher court to intervene.

The narrative then shifted to the appellate level, where the appeals court, in June 1975, reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief. This was a pivotal moment, as the appeals court, while not granting the specific relief sought, underscored the principle that prison rules must be clearly defined and justified by legitimate institutional needs. The court's decision to send the case back to the lower court for further factual development was a directive for greater transparency and scrutiny of prison practices, affirming that inmates possess fundamental rights that cannot be arbitrarily curtailed.

By this time, Sostre's plight had garnered international attention, leading Amnesty International to designate him a "prisoner of conscience." This growing public and international pressure culminated in December 1975 when New York's governor, Hugh Carey, granted Sostre clemency. His release from custody effectively rendered the ongoing legal battle over his prison conditions moot, bringing a narrative conclusion to his personal struggle within the justice system. The case officially concluded in federal records in January 1978.

original_case_data.name: Castillo v. Alameida
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: A prisoner at Pelican Bay State Prison
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On August 9, 1994, a prisoner at Pelican Bay State Prison (PBSP) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The prisoner sued the state of California under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Represented by private counsel, he claimed that the process by which an inmate is identified as a prison gang member or associate was unconstitutionally overbroad under the First Amendment and lacked due process under the Fourteenth Amendment. He also claimed that the physical conditions of the Security Housing Units (SHU) and the psychological effects of long-term SHU confinement violated the Eighth Amendment. Finally, he challenged his own gang validation, claiming it was the result of retaliation by prison officials for his jailhouse lawyering.

In 1996, the prisoner filed a second lawsuit in the Northern District of California against the California Department of Corrections, docket no. 3:96-cv-00682-MJJ. The documents in that lawsuit are not available to the Clearinghouse, so we don't know what the prisoner was challenging. He then moved to consolidate that lawsuit with this one, which had come first. On June 4, 1996, Judge Claudia Wilken granted the prisoner's motion to consolidate the two cases.

From 1995 to 2000, the parties litigated several motions to dismiss and motions for summary judgment. On May 1, 2001, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part by the District Court (Judge Martin L. Jenkins) on June 19, 2002. The District Court granted summary judgment as to the Eighth Amendment claim regarding the physical conditions of the SHU, and denied it as to the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims and the Eighth Amendment claim regarding the psychological effects of SHU confinement.

On January 5, 2004, the District Court (Judge Jenkins) partially granted another motion for summary judgment filed by defendants, finding no due process violation except to the extent that the prisoner was denied notice and an opportunity to be heard during the course of his initial validation. Further, the Court granted defendants' motion for summary judgment as to the remaining Eighth Amendment claim, finding no unconstitutional psychological effects of prolonged SHU confinement. The District Court again denied summary judgment with regard to the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims.

The parties reached a settlement in 2004. The key result of the settlement was that a prisoner would not receive an indeterminate SHU term as a validated gang member or associate without first being found to be a current, active gang member or associate consistent with the procedural safeguards in the agreement, and that periodic reviews would be required to determine whether the prisoner remained an active gang member or associate. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) agreed to propose to codify the policy changes agreed upon in the California Code of Regulations and/or the Department Operations Manual (DOM).

Specifically, the settlement provided that, with regard to due process in validations and inactive reviews, the defendants would provide notice and the opportunity to be heard to every prisoner. To this end, the defendants agreed to provide 24-hour notice to each prisoner of the items being considered as part of the determination and to provide a written record of the prisoner's opinion of these items. Further, prison officials would be required to record an "articulable basis" that prisoners were engaging in criminal or unlawful acts on behalf of a prison gang and could not rely on confidential informants unless the informants detailed the exact nature of the prisoner's involvement, without the use of hearsay evidence. The settlement also included a "single source rule," where one gang-related incident could only count as one item of evidence even though it may be reported by multiple sources. Finally, the agreement provided that plaintiff's validation would be reviewed in accordance with the settlement.

After the settlement was filed with the District Court, the case was dismissed with prejudice on November 15, 2004. The Court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, however the plaintiff's counsel agreed to a set procedure for requesting future relief from the court. If the plaintiff's counsel believed that the defendants were not complying with the provisions of the settlement agreement to make policy changes, they would notify the defendants' counsel in writing, meet to discuss the issue, and only then could they ask the court for relief. This process would be unavailable once proposed changes to the policies described in the settlement agreement were internally finalized. No individual inmate can file for relief regarding an inmate's gang validation granted; individual inmate's concerns can only be raised by the plaintiff's counsel as examples of noncompliance. The defendants also agreed to pay $240,000 that would be divided up between the plaintiff and the plaintiff's attorneys as attorneys' fees and costs.

In 2005, inmates began sending letters to the Court reporting violations of the settlement agreement. Inmates sent letters in 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, and 2012, but the Court has not responded to any of these letters or investigated the allegations.
original_case_data.summary_short: In 1994, a California prisoner filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1983 against the state of California. After nine years of litigation, the parties settled in 2004. The CDC agreed that a prisoner would not receive an indeterminate SHU term as a validated gang member  without first being found to be a current, active gang member. After the settlement was filed with the Court, the case was dismissed with prejudice in 2004.

1.transformed_text:
On August 9, 1994, a Pelican Bay State Prison (PBSP) prisoner, represented by private counsel, filed this 42 U.S.C. § 1983 lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the state of California. He claimed the inmate gang identification process was unconstitutionally overbroad (First Amendment) and lacked due process (Fourteenth Amendment). He also alleged Eighth Amendment violations regarding SHU physical conditions and the psychological effects of long-term SHU confinement. Finally, he challenged his own gang validation as retaliation for his jailhouse lawyering.

In 1996, the prisoner filed a second lawsuit in the Northern District of California against the California Department of Corrections. Judge Claudia Wilken granted the prisoner's motion to consolidate the two cases on June 4, 1996.

From 1995 to 2000, the parties litigated several motions to dismiss and for summary judgment. The District Court (Judge Martin L. Jenkins) subsequently granted in part and denied in part a defense motion for dismissal and summary judgment on June 19, 2002. Specifically, summary judgment was granted on the Eighth Amendment claim concerning SHU physical conditions, but denied as to the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims, and the Eighth Amendment claim regarding the psychological effects of SHU confinement.

On January 5, 2004, the District Court (Judge Jenkins) partially granted another defense motion for summary judgment, finding no due process violation except where the prisoner was denied notice and an opportunity to be heard during initial validation. The Court also granted summary judgment on the remaining Eighth Amendment claim, finding no unconstitutional psychological effects from prolonged SHU confinement, while again denying summary judgment on the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims.

The parties reached a settlement in 2004. A key provision stipulated that a prisoner would not receive an indeterminate SHU term as a validated gang member or associate without a finding of current, active gang membership consistent with agreed-upon procedural safeguards, and that periodic reviews would determine continued active status. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) further agreed to propose codifying these policy changes in the California Code of Regulations and/or the Department Operations Manual (DOM).

Specifically, the settlement mandated due process in validations and inactive reviews, requiring defendants to provide notice and an opportunity to be heard to every prisoner. This included 24-hour notice of items considered for determination and a written record of the prisoner's opinion. Prison officials were also required to record an "articulable basis" for findings of criminal or unlawful gang acts, prohibiting reliance on confidential informants unless they detailed the exact nature of the prisoner's involvement without hearsay. A "single source rule" was established, counting one gang-related incident as a single item of evidence regardless of multiple reporting sources. Finally, the plaintiff's own validation was to be reviewed under the settlement terms.

Following the settlement filing, the case was dismissed with prejudice on November 15, 2004, with the Court retaining jurisdiction for enforcement. Plaintiff's counsel agreed to a specific procedure for future relief: counsel would notify defense counsel in writing of non-compliance with policy changes, meet to discuss, and only then seek court intervention. This process would cease once proposed policy changes were internally finalized. Individual inmates could not file for relief regarding their validations; their concerns could only be raised by plaintiff's counsel as examples of noncompliance. Defendants also agreed to pay $240,000 for plaintiff's and plaintiff's attorneys' fees and costs.

Beginning in 2005, inmates sent multiple letters to the Court reporting settlement agreement violations through 2012, but the Court has not responded or investigated these allegations.

3.transformed_text:
The protracted litigation challenging California's inmate gang identification and Security Housing Unit (SHU) confinement processes concluded with a comprehensive settlement agreement, establishing new procedural safeguards and due process requirements, with the District Court retaining jurisdiction for enforcement.

*   **Case Genesis & Initial Rulings:** Initiated in 1994, this 42 U.S.C. § 1983 lawsuit by a Pelican Bay State Prison prisoner alleged First Amendment overbreadth regarding gang identification, Fourteenth Amendment due process violations, and Eighth Amendment issues concerning SHU conditions and psychological effects. A second 1996 suit was consolidated. Extensive motion practice led to partial summary judgments: Eighth Amendment claims on SHU physical conditions and psychological effects were dismissed, but First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims, and Fourteenth Amendment due process for initial validation notice/hearing, survived.

*   **Settlement Core & Policy Changes:** The 2004 settlement stipulated that indeterminate SHU terms for validated gang members require a finding of current, active gang membership, subject to agreed procedural safeguards and periodic reviews. CDCR committed to proposing codification of these policy changes in the California Code of Regulations and/or Department Operations Manual (DOM).

*   **Enhanced Due Process & Evidence Rules:** The agreement mandated due process in validations and inactive reviews, requiring defendants to provide notice and an opportunity to be heard, including 24-hour notice of considered items and a written record of opinion. Prison officials must record an "articulable basis" for findings of criminal/unlawful gang acts, prohibiting reliance on confidential informants unless detailing exact involvement without hearsay. A "single source rule" was established, counting one gang-related incident as a single item regardless of multiple reports. The plaintiff's own validation was also subject to review under these terms.

*   **Enforcement & Financial Resolution:** Following settlement filing, the case was dismissed with prejudice, with the Court retaining jurisdiction for enforcement. Plaintiff's counsel agreed to a specific enforcement protocol: written notification of non-compliance, meeting with defense counsel, then court intervention, ceasing once policy changes were internally finalized. Individual inmates cannot seek relief directly; concerns must be raised by plaintiff's counsel as non-compliance examples. Defendants paid $240,000 for plaintiff's and attorneys' fees and costs. Inmates reported alleged violations post-2005, but the Court has not responded.

*   **Why?** The plaintiff alleged First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation regarding gang identification, Fourteenth Amendment due process violations concerning gang identification and Security Housing Unit (SHU) confinement, and Eighth Amendment issues regarding SHU conditions and psychological effects. *   **What Happened?** Protracted litigation concluded with a comprehensive settlement. These include enhanced due process with notice, opportunity to be heard, "articulable basis" for findings, and strict evidence rules like a "single source rule" and limited confidential informant reliance. 0.text:
On August 9, 1994, a prisoner at Pelican Bay State Prison (PBSP) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The prisoner sued the state of California under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Represented by private counsel, he claimed that the process by which an inmate is identified as a prison gang member or associate was unconstitutionally overbroad under the First Amendment and lacked due process under the Fourteenth Amendment. He also claimed that the physical conditions of the Security Housing Units (SHU) and the psychological effects of long-term SHU confinement violated the Eighth Amendment. Finally, he challenged his own gang validation, claiming it was the result of retaliation by prison officials for his jailhouse lawyering.

In 1996, the prisoner filed a second lawsuit in the Northern District of California against the California Department of Corrections, docket no. 3:96-cv-00682-MJJ. The documents in that lawsuit are not available to the Clearinghouse, so we don't know what the prisoner was challenging. He then moved to consolidate that lawsuit with this one, which had come first. On June 4, 1996, Judge Claudia Wilken granted the prisoner's motion to consolidate the two cases.

From 1995 to 2000, the parties litigated several motions to dismiss and motions for summary judgment. On May 1, 2001, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part by the District Court (Judge Martin L. Jenkins) on June 19, 2002. The District Court granted summary judgment as to the Eighth Amendment claim regarding the physical conditions of the SHU, and denied it as to the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims and the Eighth Amendment claim regarding the psychological effects of SHU confinement.

On January 5, 2004, the District Court (Judge Jenkins) partially granted another motion for summary judgment filed by defendants, finding no due process violation except to the extent that the prisoner was denied notice and an opportunity to be heard during the course of his initial validation. Further, the Court granted defendants' motion for summary judgment as to the remaining Eighth Amendment claim, finding no unconstitutional psychological effects of prolonged SHU confinement. The District Court again denied summary judgment with regard to the First Amendment overbreadth and retaliation claims.

The parties reached a settlement in 2004. The key result of the settlement was that a prisoner would not receive an indeterminate SHU term as a validated gang member or associate without first being found to be a current, active gang member or associate consistent with the procedural safeguards in the agreement, and that periodic reviews would be required to determine whether the prisoner remained an active gang member or associate. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) agreed to propose to codify the policy changes agreed upon in the California Code of Regulations and/or the Department Operations Manual (DOM).

Specifically, the settlement provided that, with regard to due process in validations and inactive reviews, the defendants would provide notice and the opportunity to be heard to every prisoner. To this end, the defendants agreed to provide 24-hour notice to each prisoner of the items being considered as part of the determination and to provide a written record of the prisoner's opinion of these items. Further, prison officials would be required to record an "articulable basis" that prisoners were engaging in criminal or unlawful acts on behalf of a prison gang and could not rely on confidential informants unless the informants detailed the exact nature of the prisoner's involvement, without the use of hearsay evidence. The settlement also included a "single source rule," where one gang-related incident could only count as one item of evidence even though it may be reported by multiple sources. Finally, the agreement provided that plaintiff's validation would be reviewed in accordance with the settlement.

After the settlement was filed with the District Court, the case was dismissed with prejudice on November 15, 2004. The Court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, however the plaintiff's counsel agreed to a set procedure for requesting future relief from the court. If the plaintiff's counsel believed that the defendants were not complying with the provisions of the settlement agreement to make policy changes, they would notify the defendants' counsel in writing, meet to discuss the issue, and only then could they ask the court for relief. This process would be unavailable once proposed changes to the policies described in the settlement agreement were internally finalized. No individual inmate can file for relief regarding an inmate's gang validation granted; individual inmate's concerns can only be raised by the plaintiff's counsel as examples of noncompliance. The defendants also agreed to pay $240,000 that would be divided up between the plaintiff and the plaintiff's attorneys as attorneys' fees and costs.

In 2005, inmates began sending letters to the Court reporting violations of the settlement agreement. Inmates sent letters in 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, and 2012, but the Court has not responded to any of these letters or investigated the allegations.

1.transformed_text:
On August 9, 1994, a prisoner at Pelican Bay State Prison (PBSP) sued the state of California in federal court in Northern California, claiming a violation of his civil rights. With his own lawyer, he argued that the way prisoners were identified as gang members was too broad under the First Amendment (free speech) and didn't follow fair legal procedures (due process) under the Fourteenth Amendment. He also claimed that the physical conditions and long-term mental impact of being held in Security Housing Units (SHU) violated the Eighth Amendment (cruel and unusual punishment). Finally, he argued his own gang identification was unfair, saying prison officials targeted him because he helped other inmates with their legal issues.

In 1996, the prisoner filed a second lawsuit in the same federal court against the California Department of Corrections. We don't know what this second lawsuit was about, as its records are not available. He then asked the court to combine this new case with his first one. On June 4, 1996, Judge Claudia Wilken allowed him to combine the two cases.

From 1995 to 2000, both sides argued various legal requests, including motions to dismiss the case and motions for summary judgment. On May 1, 2001, the defendants filed another motion to dismiss and for summary judgment. On June 19, 2002, the District Court (Judge Martin L. Jenkins) approved some parts of it and rejected others. The court sided with the defendants on the Eighth Amendment claim about the physical conditions in SHU. However, it allowed the First Amendment claims (overbreadth and retaliation) and the Eighth Amendment claim about the psychological effects of SHU to continue.

On January 5, 2004, Judge Jenkins again partly sided with the defendants on another summary judgment motion. The court found no violation of due process, except for when the prisoner was first identified as a gang member and wasn't given proper notice or a chance to speak. The court also ruled in favor of the defendants on the remaining Eighth Amendment claim, deciding that long-term SHU confinement did not cause unconstitutional psychological harm. But the court once more rejected summary judgment for the First Amendment claims (overbreadth and retaliation).

The parties settled the case in 2004. A main part of the settlement was that a prisoner identified as a gang member would not be sent to SHU indefinitely unless they were proven to be a current, active gang member, following specific rules in the agreement. Also, regular reviews would be needed to check if the prisoner was still an active gang member. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) agreed to propose writing these new policy changes into the California Code of Regulations or their Department Operations Manual (DOM).

Specifically, for due process in identifying gang members and reviewing inactive cases, the settlement required defendants to give every prisoner notice and a chance to speak. This meant defendants would give prisoners 24-hour notice of the evidence against them and create a written record of the prisoner's response. Also, prison officials had to clearly state why they believed prisoners were involved in illegal gang activities. They could not rely on secret informants unless those informants provided specific details about the prisoner's involvement, without using hearsay (second-hand information). The settlement also had a "single source rule," meaning one gang-related incident could only count as one piece of evidence, even if reported by many sources. Finally, the agreement stated that the plaintiff's own gang identification would be reviewed under these new rules.

After the settlement was filed with the District Court, the case was permanently closed on November 15, 2004. However, the Court kept the power to make sure the settlement was followed. The plaintiff's lawyer agreed to a specific process for asking the court for help in the future. If the plaintiff's lawyer thought the defendants weren't following the settlement's policy changes, they first had to tell the defendants' lawyer in writing, then meet to discuss it, and only then could they ask the court for help. This specific process would no longer apply once the proposed policy changes from the settlement were officially made permanent within the prison system. Individual inmates could not directly sue about their gang identifications. Instead, their concerns could only be brought up by the plaintiff's lawyer as examples of the prison system not following the agreement. The defendants also agreed to pay $240,000 to cover the plaintiff's and his lawyers' fees and costs.

Starting in 2005, inmates began sending letters to the Court, claiming the settlement agreement was being violated. Inmates sent letters in 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, and 2012, but the Court has not replied to any of them or looked into the claims.
